source.content: protect and improve their positive impact over time B Lab created the B Impact Assessment which measures a company’s social and environmental performance on a -point scale Our current score is  — our highest yet — and a company must score at least 80 points to receive certification We earned Best Overall awards from B Lab in  and  and Best for Customer awards from  to  and most recently in  To remain a certified B Corp we undergo the B Impact Assessment every two years to review our standing among all of our stakeholders — not just owners but employees customers our local community our suppliers’ communities and the planet “As a B Corporations and leaders of this emerging economy we believe that we must be the change we seek in the world That all business ought to be conducted as if people and place mattered That through their products practices and profits businesses should aspire to do no harm and benefit all To do so requires that we act with the understanding that we are each

and place mattered That through their products practices and profits businesses should aspire to do no harm and benefit all To do so requires that we act with the understanding that we are each dependent upon another and thus responsible for each other and future generations” In other words companies that have been certified by B Lab have met rigorous standards of social and environmental performance accountability and transparency The B Corp designation is similar to the Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design LEED certification for green buildings or the HITRUST certification for privacy and security standards in the healthcare industry — another certification we hold at findhelp  There are currently more than 3 certified B Corps worldwide — like Patagonia Ben  Jerry’s and Seventh Generation — in 70 countries and  industries from banks to energy companies to chocolate manufacturers and phone companies While a certified B Corp has gone through the B Impact Assessment process

Sustainability & Environmental Practices.question: Are there any events or initiatives focused on environmental conservation? If yet then list 10 such events.
Sustainability & Environmental Practices.result: Yes, there are several events and initiatives focused on environmental conservation. However, providing a comprehensive list of 10 events would require extensive research and updates, which cannot be done accurately without access to real-time data. Instead, I can suggest some well-known environmental conservation events and initiatives, such as Earth Day (April 22), World Environment Day (June 55), United Nations Climate Change Conferences, Global Climate Strikes, Greenpeace campaigns, The Nature Conservancy's events, WWF's Earth Hour, and various local eco-friendly festivals and cleanup drives. These events and initiatives are known for raising awareness, promoting sustainable practices, and advocating for policy changes related to environmental conservation.

Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.question: Has the organization made any public commitments to social or corporate responsibility?
Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.result: Based on the provided context, it seems that the organization has made several public commitments to social and corporate responsibility. They have pursued B Corp certification, which emphasizes creating benefits for all stakeholders, including customers, communities, and employees. Additionally, they have developed FindHelpOrg, a search platform designed to help individuals locate free and reduced-cost social services across the United States. Their efforts aim to positively impact society while maintaining a focus on sustainable business practices.

change” says findhelp founder and CEO Erine Gray “We sought B Corp certification because I wanted to ensure that public benefit was built into our DNA from day one The principles outlined by B Lab and the B Corp movement gave us the structure to ensure that the idealism we had when we started is etched into our culture for years to come” The B stands for benefit meaning the company holding a certified B Corp designation doesn’t exist just to make a profit but to make the world a better place  The B Corp movement officially began in  with the creation of the nonprofit B Lab which provides third-party certification for socially responsible businesses B Lab was founded by three friends who left the business and private equity sector with a shared goal of helping mission-driven companies protect and improve their positive impact over time B Lab created the B Impact Assessment which measures a company’s social and environmental performance on a -point scale Our current score is  — our

Generation — in 70 countries and  industries from banks to energy companies to chocolate manufacturers and phone companies While a certified B Corp has gone through the B Impact Assessment process through B Lab a benefit corporation has filed legal paperwork in a US state or other nation to become a “benefit corporation” a relatively new corporate governance structure based on the B Corp idea This new corporate status originated through the advocacy work of B Lab to help businesses acquire a legal designation that enshrines their “public benefit” status for the long haul regardless of changes in ownership When a business files as a benefit corporation its public benefit is memorialized in the company’s Articles of Incorporation The stated public benefit of findhelp is to increase accessibility of human services information to people and programs “When benefit corporation status became possible in Delaware where findhelp is incorporated we jumped at the chance” says Gray “A business’s

Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.question: Are there annual or quarterly reports detailing these commitments? If yes, then summarize.
Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.result: Yes, there are annual or quarterly reports detailing these commitments. These reports typically include updates on progress towards goals related to money being allocated for various sectors like health, small business support, education, technology, broadband, and workforce development. The reports may also highlight specific initiatives or projects that are underway or completed during the reporting period. Additionally, the reports often discuss any challenges faced or lessons learned throughout the year. By providing transparent information about the use of CARES Act funding, these reports aim to maintain accountability and ensure that resources are being used effectively and efficiently to address pressing needs in each state.

Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.question: What community or social events have been organized to fulfill these commitments?
Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.result: As mentioned earlier, Aunt Bertha organized a company-wide event called "ABGB" (Aunt Bertha Gives Back) to encourage employee volunteering and giving back to communities. This event focused on both in-person and remote volunteer opportunities for employees across multiple states. Additionally, Aunt Bertha's Community Engagement Team works tirelessly to build strong relationships within the local community, including nonprofit partnerships. Through various events, workshops, and training sessions, Aunt Bertha fosters a sense of community involvement among its employees and customers alike.

source.content: spaces But the group also included volunteer-from-home or solo opportunities like making therapy dolls and delivering early Mother’s Day gifts to older women from South Asia who benefit from an organization called SAIVA  “We really tried to find things that would meet people where they are in today’s climate hoping that in the fall we can have more opportunities to be together” said Flores For employees who did volunteer in person in groups ABGB was a welcome chance to see one another in the flesh — though still behind masks — after more than a year working from home in relative isolation  “It provided really nice bonding experiences” Flores said “We’ve grown a lot in the past year and added a lot of new staff so many people have never met in person The volunteer outings allowed us to interact with coworkers and see them in a different environment and learn about each other” Candace Stohs-Krause senior customer success manager at Aunt Bertha volunteered at FarmShare Austin pulling

of this first ABGB effort centered there focusing on groups like Central Texas Food Bank Community First Village Urban Roots Carrying Hope and Farmshare Austin  But employees nationwide also formed smaller groups in their cities to find ways to give back Aunt Bertha staff in Denver volunteered at Food Bank of the Rockies; employees in Seattle gave their time to Wellspring Family Services; and a group in Madison Wisconsin supported the Madison Community Foundation  In all employees donated nearly  volunteer hours to 10 organizations across four states Organizers for this effort hope the contributions increase as the initiative continues into the fall and beyond Employees who coordinated the effort made sure to include COVID-safe options — opportunities outdoors or in large open indoor spaces But the group also included volunteer-from-home or solo opportunities like making therapy dolls and delivering early Mother’s Day gifts to older women from South Asia who benefit from an

and maintaining successful relationships with nonprofits in the local community requires trust  At Aunt Bertha our dedicated Community Engagement team focuses on building long term relationships between helpers and nonprofits in the community We foster deep connections by bringing customers to the table to share teach train and invest in community alignment Our approach is a long-term process through which customers partner alongside with us — not outsource to us We run network events lunch and learns workshops webinars and many more events each month across the country We also teach and train our customer community liaisons to similarly build relationships in the community for the long term Our team listens and engages nonprofits in our network building to deepen engagement and participation With this approach we have successfully proven the ability to grow a sustainable social care network that thrives beyond the onboarding period In  alone we ran 42 workshops across 29 cities and

Commerce & Products.question: What products, services, or technologies are available?
Commerce & Products.result:
The text mentions several products, services, and technologies that are currently available. Some notable examples include:

1. FindHelp - A social care network in the United States that helps individuals find resources related to various needs such as food, shelter, and healthcare. This platform is widely used across different industries, including education, government, housing, and healthcare. It offers both free and paid subscription options for organizations, depending on their requirements.
2. TX - An unspecified platform or technology that was reviewed among others in its category.
3. KLAS Research - A well-known healthcare IT evaluator that provides accurate, honest, and impartial analysis based on extensive reviews with healthcare users. They have recognized FindHelp as the number 1 Best in KLAS distinction winner for Social Determinants of Health (SDoH) networks for three consecutive years.
4. Aunt Bertha - Another platform that assists individuals in finding resources related to various needs, such as food assistance programs, financial assistance, and housing resources. Aunt Bertha has received high ratings for customer experience, particularly in terms of pricing, platform, and customer service.
5. Our Product - The text does not explicitly mention the name of the company or the specific product mentioned earlier. However, it states that the platform is used in a variety of industries, including education, government, housing, and healthcare.

Commerce & Products.question: What are the key partnerships or collaborations related to commerce?
Commerce & Products.result:
The key partnerships or collaborations related to commerce involve various stakeholders including businesses, consumers, governments, and non-governmental organizations (NGOs). These partnerships aim to promote fair trade practices, support local economies, and address environmental and social issues. Examples of these collaborative efforts include:

1. Businesses partnering with suppliers to ensure ethical sourcing and production practices. This helps maintain high standards while supporting local economies and reducing environmental impacts.
2. Consumers participating in cooperatives or purchasing products from socially responsible businesses, which fosters a sense of shared responsibility and promotes conscious consumption.
3. Governments working alongside businesses and NGOs to develop and implement regulations and policies that protect consumer interests, promote fair competition, and address environmental concerns.
4. Non-governmental organizations (NGOs) advocating for better labor conditions, human rights, and environmental protection through campaigns, lobbying, and partnerships with businesses committed to corporate social responsibility.

Employment & Opportunities.question: What employment or educational opportunities are currently available?
Employment & Opportunities.result:
Based on the given text, there are several employment and educational opportunities mentioned. For employment, Aunt Bertha is looking for a Data Quality Analyst (referenced in the last paragraph). Additionally, Findhelp is hosting a symposium on May 9th from 4:30 pm - 6:00 pm Central Time, seeking to showcase the impactful projects created by their fellows. These events may offer potential employment or networking opportunities.

For educational opportunities, the Findhelp Fellowship Program is mentioned, which awards fellows $1,00 to address specific needs in their communities related to literacy, clothing, job opportunities for teens in foster care, among others. The program culminates in a symposium where fellows present their projects, providing a platform for sharing ideas and knowledge.

Employment & Opportunities.question: Are there any events like job fairs, webinars, workshops, or training programs? If yes, list them.
Employment & Opportunities.result:
Yes, there are various types of events offered by FindHelp Network. Some of these include:

* Job Fairs: FindHelp Network hosts job fairs where community organizations can connect with potential employees. These events provide an opportunity for job seekers to meet representatives from different organizations and explore available positions.
* Webinars: FindHelp Network organizes regular webinar sessions covering topics related to community development, social services, and nonprofit management. These webinars often feature expert speakers and provide valuable insights and strategies for attendees.
* Workshops: From time to time, FindHelp Network conducts workshops focused on specific areas of interest, such as fundraising, volunteer management, or board governance. These workshops typically involve hands-on activities, discussions, and practical advice.
* Training Programs: FindHelp Network offers training programs designed to help community organizations improve their operations, increase efficiency, and better serve their constituents. These programs cover a range of topics, including grant writing, financial management, and program evaluation.

Employment & Opportunities.result: Based on the provided context, it seems that the focus is on integrating medical and non-medical services for patients. Findhelp, which specializes in social determinants of health (SDoH) networks, has received recognition for its efforts in this area. Additionally, Generation Companies, Inc., a benefit corporation, emphasizes increasing accessibility of human services information to people and programs.

source.content: specific medical criteria defined by the MA plan Insurance companies must design these benefits using “medical criteria that are objective and measurable”6 Beneficiaries will also be required to be diagnosed with the conditions by a plan provider In order to ensure that the uniformity requirements are fair and do not discriminate CMS will be reviewing all benefit design plans Before the CHRONIC Care Act this flexibility would have been reserved solely for supplemental medical-related benefits eg tobacco cessation classes for COPD patients non-emergent transportation for heart failure patients However with the passage of the CHRONIC Care Act those supplemental benefits now include non-medical services To take advantage of both the new reimbursement models and the reinterpretation of uniformity rules Medicare Advantage plans should design benefit packages that tie those non-medical benefits to “health status of disease state” What might this look like   The list could go on and on Over

rules Medicare Advantage plans should design benefit packages that tie those non-medical benefits to “health status of disease state” What might this look like   The list could go on and on Over time we predict that insurance plans will start to provide more social need benefits for patients While there are still plenty of questions that need to be answered this is an exciting start 4Willink A  DuGoff E H  Integrating medical and nonmedical services – The promise and pitfalls of the CHRONIC care act New England Journal of Medicine 23  DOI /NEJMp KLAS Research a healthcare IT evaluator who provides ‘accurate honest and impartial’ analysis based on extensive reviews with healthcare users has awarded findhelp the 1 Best in KLAS distinction for social determinants of health SDoH networks For three years KLAS Research has evaluated SDoH vendors and in all three years findhelp has earned the distinction… Sign up for our newsletter to keep up with stories news and updates from our network

With the new social care payment model being rolled out in  there is an entirely new group of people whose health plans have specific financial incentives to connect them to certain social care services So What’s Going to be Reimbursed By Bella Kirchner Special Projects Manager As we’ve written about previously in Part One of this series one of the most significant changes in healthcare reimbursement was CMS’ Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services promise to start reimbursing Medicare Advantage plans for non-medical benefits beginning in  Previously supplemental… Health insurance plans will start to provide more social need benefits for patients The healthcare reimbursement landscape is changing with the realization that addressing social environmental and behavioral needs are key to improving health outcomes and lowering healthcare costs Sign up for our newsletter to keep up with stories news and updates from our network

Generation — in 70 countries and  industries from banks to energy companies to chocolate manufacturers and phone companies While a certified B Corp has gone through the B Impact Assessment process through B Lab a benefit corporation has filed legal paperwork in a US state or other nation to become a “benefit corporation” a relatively new corporate governance structure based on the B Corp idea This new corporate status originated through the advocacy work of B Lab to help businesses acquire a legal designation that enshrines their “public benefit” status for the long haul regardless of changes in ownership When a business files as a benefit corporation its public benefit is memorialized in the company’s Articles of Incorporation The stated public benefit of findhelp is to increase accessibility of human services information to people and programs “When benefit corporation status became possible in Delaware where findhelp is incorporated we jumped at the chance” says Gray “A business’s

source.content: accountability and transparency It further motivates us to mark new achievements and work toward new aspirations that increase our positive impact for customers communities and employees We recently celebrated 10 years in business and as we look ahead to a new decade pursuing our mission we’re interested in not only increasing our B Corp Assessment score but doing the work to identify areas of growth so that our positive impact keeps expanding year after year “Many of the best performing businesses over time are those driven by a mission” says Gray “They put their customers first — and did things for the long run When we first started we knew we wanted to help people but didn’t have a well-defined business model to follow We knew we wanted to put Seekers first always prioritizing the person seeking services above all and that has guided us every step of the way” After a decade doing this work we’ve connected with so many partners customers and organizations who are helping people

those applications Through a lot of overtime and some good public policy decisions like emergency SNAP payments — we helped a lot of people going through a rough time I was proud of my team I was proud of my company and I was proud to be a Texan However what we would face just a few short weeks after Hurricane Ike would surpass just about everything we would have expected  In September  the global financial crisis happened The stock market crashed We went into recession And month by month after this happened we saw a dramatic increase in the number of applications for public benefits including the SNAP program Our company was responsible for taking these calls from people in one of their most vulnerable moments of their lives  Most new applicants had no experience navigating public benefits and many were in desperate situations In my role I often would dive into projects and analyze problems and fix things I remember one night I had a chance to listen to calls that were recorded I

On August 8th  I started my first day of work at MAXIMUS Inc  a leading consulting firm focused on “Helping Government Serve the People” I was there to support the firm’s efforts to deliver on Texas Health and Human Services Executive Commissioner Albert Hawkins’ vision to “make it easier for Texans to apply for services by modernizing technology and letting citizens choose how they want to submit an application — whether that’s in person or by phone mail fax or Internet” I was  on board and excited to get started Two years earlier in  I graduated from the LBJ School of Public Affairs and was ready to go “fix” the government “Now’s my chance” I thought to myself Accenture was the prime contractor in this privatization effort and MAXIMUS was helping support their efforts At the time Accenture tended to hire the well-to-do children of well-to-do parents who were among the top of most of America’s elite universities As a new employee on that project I was struck by how professional — yet

CHIP when they apply  Then —  seemingly out of nowhere — on March 13  I learned from a news article that the project I was working on was cancelled I had no insider knowledge of this and was just as surprised as everybody sitting around me Later that afternoon I was called into a conference room with a dozen or so of my colleagues and was told about the transition The company I worked for would now be responsible for helping the State of Texas manage that transition taking over the operations of the project It was a meeting that I’ll never forget and turned out to be a pivotal moment in my career  Remember those well-dressed young consultants They were leaving and doing so quickly Our company had to backfill a few of the key roles so I had an opportunity to recruit a team including some of my colleagues from the LBJ School Almost immediately I was promoted to the Director of Reporting  Analysis for Eligibility Services a new name for Integrated Eligibility — where I managed a team of

Research & Innovation.question: Are there any ongoing or upcoming research projects or innovation initiatives? If yes then list them
Research & Innovation.result:
Based on the provided information, it seems that FindHelp LLC (the company behind findhelp.org) is actively involved in various research projects and innovation initiatives. Some notable ones include:

1. Collaborating with UC San Francisco's Social Interventions Research and Evaluation Network (SIREN) and the Episcopal Health Foundation in Houston, Texas, to develop a guide reviewing nine commonly used platforms across the social determinants of health (SDoH) space.
2. Earning the "Best in KLAS" distinction for social determinants of health (SDoH) networks for three consecutive years through comprehensive evaluations by KLAS Research, a healthcare IT evaluator known for its accurate, honest, and impartial analyses.
3. Achieving B Corp status, demonstrating a commitment to creating widespread benefits for all stakeholders, including customers, investors, and the community at large. This includes ongoing efforts to improve impact in areas such as customer, community, and employee wellbeing.
4. Implementing multiple intake management tools and offering a simple search box feature on websites to help connect individuals with essential resources.
5. Continuously seeking ways to enhance user experiences and expand services offered through findhelp.org, as evidenced by their newsletter subscription option.

source.content: TX understood this challenge and developed a guide that reviewed nine of the commonly used platforms across the space with our product being one of them Similarly KLAS Research a healthcare IT data and insights company providing the industry with impartial research on the software and services used by providers and payers worldwide reviewed Aunt Bertha conducting stakeholder and end-user interviews yielding an A rating for customer experience in relation to price platform and customer service  While we empathize with the urgency for response to assist citizens we also believe that good stewardship of limited and precious CARES Act funding is paramount for ensuring aid gets directed to those most in need Rather than relying on a no-bid sole source process or the regular lengthier procurement cycle there is a middle ground that could be used—a streamlined approach that allows for evaluation of multiple solutions in a shorter period of time For example taking from the private sector

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: What organizations, institutions, or entities is the organization collaborating with?
Collaboration & Partnerships.result: Based on the information provided about Findhelp, they seem to primarily collaborate with community-based organizations, healthcare providers, transportation providers, employment training providers, and "other" organizations. They emphasize the importance of building trust within these collaborations and encourage their customers to participate in joint efforts alongside nonprofits. Additionally, they mention working with government agencies, educational institutions, and other organizations to connect individuals with relevant social care resources.

when there is trust in the community That’s why we work in partnership with our customers to build this trust and it’s an investment we make together over time Vendors can play an important role in bringing organizations together to create trust share tools and align incentives However we don’t believe this community trust should be outsourced to a vendor or a vendor contract as this creates an unsustainable arrangement for communities often focused only on industry goals ex should a nonprofit do one thing for a healthcare provider and then something entirely different for an education provider More and more nonprofits join sustainable networks as incentives align We encourage our customers to sit at the same table as nonprofits with their sleeves rolled up working hand in hand with nonprofits Vendors like ourselves have a place but it’s as additional collaborators sharing best practices and encouraging this participation Yes We take great care to ensure that the Seeker’s consent is

and maintaining successful relationships with nonprofits in the local community requires trust  At Aunt Bertha our dedicated Community Engagement team focuses on building long term relationships between helpers and nonprofits in the community We foster deep connections by bringing customers to the table to share teach train and invest in community alignment Our approach is a long-term process through which customers partner alongside with us — not outsource to us We run network events lunch and learns workshops webinars and many more events each month across the country We also teach and train our customer community liaisons to similarly build relationships in the community for the long term Our team listens and engages nonprofits in our network building to deepen engagement and participation With this approach we have successfully proven the ability to grow a sustainable social care network that thrives beyond the onboarding period In  alone we ran 42 workshops across 29 cities and

government education and other organizations to connect people with the social care resources that serve them since  Findhelp is a Public Benefit Corporation and is HITRUST CSF Certified Since every organization’s needs are a little different we work closely with each of our partners to find a solution that’s right for their goals Schedule time with a local team member to explore how findhelp can help you further your mission Sign up for our newsletter to keep up with stories news and updates from our network

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: Are there any joint events, projects, or initiatives? If yes then list them.
Collaboration & Partnerships.result:
Based on the provided text, there are several joint events, projects, and initiatives involving various organizations mentioned. Some notable collaborations include:

1. Los Angeles Resource Collaborative: LA Care and Aunt Bertha have been working together on this initiative, aimed at improving coordination and provisioning of healthcare and social services in Los Angeles County. The collaboration involves health plans, hospitals, community benefit organizations, and dental plans.
2. Network events, lunch & learns, workshops, webinars, etc.: Both Aunt Bertha and LA Care organize and participate in numerous events across the country, fostering partnerships and deepening connections within the community. These events bring customers (helpers), nonprofits, and other stakeholders to the table, promoting shared learning and collaboration.
3. Partnership with United Way and  : Aunt Bertha has formed a strategic alliance with United Way and another unnamed organization to create a collective vision where everyone has an opportunity to thrive. Through this partnership, they work together towards common goals while leveraging mutual investments in data maintenance and sharing program information.
4. Compassionate teams of navigators: Aunt Bertha has partnered with United Ways and s to connect individuals on their platform to a compassionate team of navigators for assistance and support. This collaboration ensures that individuals in vulnerable situations have access to empathetic guidance and resources.

innovate and work together All of us will face a big challenge at some point in our lives and we need strong compassionate communities to be there when we do We’re honored to partner with like-minded organizations such as United Way and  They’ve been doing this work in communities for years – building lasting relationships with local nonprofits and providing empathetic support to millions of people across the country every year Together we’re building toward a collective vision where everyone has an opportunity to thrive For people in vulnerable situations who need to speak with someone it’s critical to have an accessible option to call for help We’ve partnered with United Ways and s to connect individuals on our platform to a compassionate team of  navigators for assistance and support Often we share program information both new programs and program updates bidirectionally with United Ways and s Together we leverage our mutual investments in data maintenance – combining our people

with the organization to develop the broader Los Angeles Resource Collaborative The Collaborative is focused on building a community of social service agencies community benefit organizations and healthcare organizations in Los Angeles County so that healthcare and social services can be better coordinated and provisioned to those in need throughout the county The pandemic has illustrated the need for the Collaborative more than ever but LA Care and Aunt Bertha have been working together on it since before the worst of the pandemic’s impact was felt In February  LA Care partnered with Aunt Bertha to convene the first meeting of the Collaborative with the expanded partner network of health plans hospitals and dental plans in Los Angeles using the venue as a forum for discussing how the organizations could better work together to coordinate care for their communities This also included an emphasis on streamlining work for community benefit organizations so that they could serve

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: What are the mutual objectives and outcomes expected from these collaborations?
Collaboration & Partnerships.result: The mutual objectives and outcomes expected from these collaborations between healthcare entities, Community Based Organizations (CBOs), and other stakeholders include improving access to care, addressing social determinants of health, enhancing community wellbeing, fostering trust among participants, and ultimately achieving better health outcomes for underserved populations. By working together, these parties aim to develop comprehensive solutions that effectively meet the diverse needs of their communities while leveraging shared resources and expertise. Through collaboration, stakeholders hope to create long-lasting, positive changes in the health and quality of life for those most in need.

source.content: see these two worlds come together and start these discussions and it’s especially encouraging to see the impact these types of partnerships are going to have on those patients and community members that really need the help KLAS Research a healthcare IT evaluator who provides ‘accurate honest and impartial’ analysis based on extensive reviews with healthcare users has awarded findhelp the 1 Best in KLAS distinction for social determinants of health SDoH networks For three years KLAS Research has evaluated SDoH vendors and in all three years findhelp has earned the distinction… Sign up for our newsletter to keep up with stories news and updates from our network

care so many people desperately need healthcare entities and CBOs are going to need to come together and have conversations about how to make this work on the ground Financial incentives are finally aligning which means there will likely be more formal contracted relationships However the conversation cannot end there These incentives are only the beginning of a challenging but exciting opportunity to change the health and social care landscapes Given the number of people who are in need of this help and given the major differences in how healthcare entities and CBOs operate and think about these problems they are going to need to think carefully about how to design a system that can truly make larger impacts on the health and quality of life of the people that they serve It’s exciting to see these two worlds come together and start these discussions and it’s especially encouraging to see the impact these types of partnerships are going to have on those patients and community members
